summary: This document is a series of emails from September 2020 between FBI personnel discussing the approval and cost estimate for a trip to London to interview an important witness in the Epstein/Maxwell investigation. The travel was planned for October 12-17, 2020, and involved two FBI agents and two Assistant U.S. Attorneys from the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: M I
persons.context: FBI agent from the New York Field Office, Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking unit, who is planning to travel to London to interview a witness in the Epstein/Maxwell case.

connections.description: FBI agents from the same field office and unit, planning to travel together to London for a witness interview.

events.title: Planned FBI travel to London for witness interview
events.description: FBI agents and Assistant U.S. Attorneys planned to travel to London to interview an important witness in the Epstein/Maxwell investigation in person, as the witness was not comfortable speaking at length via video.

events.title: Cancelled travel to London due to Covid
events.description: Initial plans for FBI agents and AUSAs to travel to London in March 2020 to interview a witness were cancelled due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

keyFacts: In September 2020, the FBI was actively pursuing the Epstein/Maxwell investigation, planning international travel to interview a key witness who insisted on an in-person meeting.
The witness was described as 'important' to the investigation and was uncomfortable discussing the case at length via video conference.
The planned trip involved two FBI agents from the New York Field Office's Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking unit and two Assistant U.S. Attorneys from SDNY.
The email chain reveals internal FBI procedures for approving international travel, including cost estimates and approvals from division SAC and IOD.
Multiple names and email addresses in the document are redacted, indicating sensitivity around the investigation participants.
